options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

comments: One-on-one virtual tutorial sessions weekly

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: more advanced Chinese grammar, vocabulary, talking about relevant subjects
I learned new vocabulary to discuss complex topics in Chinese. I also learned new grammar structures, particularly those that are used in formal writing.
I learned a lot of new vocabulary and sentence/phrase patterns, and I learned about several aspects of Chinese history and society
I learned how to incorporate vocabulary into my own usage of Chinese rather than just understanding the words. I also learned about different cultures and issues in Chinese.
advanced Chinese instruction

We learned how to engage in more formal conversations with Chinese, covering topics ranging from gender inequality, to the AIDs epidemic in Henan. We learned how to use more formal grammar structures in our conversation compared to earlier semesters of Chinese.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this course worked very well, even in the online format. Discussion was structured and not nearly as awkward as other Zoom seminars because of its structure

Strengths: It is very well organized and we learned an incredibly large number of grammar structures and new words in a short period of time. 

One improvement that could be made: I think it would be helpful for the students to speak more to each other in Chinese to improve every day conversations, but I understand that this was limited this year due to the Zoom class format.

I found the content relevant and interesting. 
I wish the PowerPoints were more organized so they would be better to look back at and review for exams.
I think the course was taught very well and at a good pace. I also think that the structure of the course was very helpful for efficient and productive learning.

Strengths - professor, interactive classroom, useful TA
Weaknesses - My section was a bit too big which made speaking difficult.

The Chinese professors give great feedback on individualized strengths and weaknesses so that we can improve. This semester, we were not able to talk a lot in class so it was harder to be engaged and practice our speaking skills.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: the use of more breakout rooms could be a fun way to have students get to know one another a bit more

I think the lecture format worked well, and it was helpful to have all of the power points and other class materials available online. The student participation could have been improved by using more breakout rooms, but the students were actually engaged much better than in some of my other classes because they were called on regularly.

I think tutorial was nice since it was one-on-one but I found the class discussions to be less interactive. I presume it was possibly the case because of our class size, but I wish we could go around and review the examples more by saying them out loud
I think that virtual discussion sections and having powerpoints available online were great. Using external websites and learning tools did not work as well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I loved this course and the material was very engaging and felt like we were learning how to talk about important and controversial topics

Yes, I think that this course drastically improved my knowledge of Chinese characters, history, and culture. I have taken Chinese for over 8 years, and this is by far the strongest Chinese program that I have ever been a part of due to its organization and thoroughness.
Yes if you are interested in continuing to improve your Chinese language skills and learn more about Chinese culture and history
Yes because even though it was a hard class, I learned a lot in a short period of time and I did not feel overwhelmed.
Yes if you want to continue your study in Chinese.

Yes. It was really fun to learn how to use Chinese in more formal conversations which was very different from previous Chinese courses at Yale. If you want to really increase your ability to engage in more complex conversations in Chinese, I highly recommend taking Chinese 150.
